Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2011 07:55PM Anniemomofthree wrote: Hi All - and welcome back again Visi - I think things will make more sense when you have your CT/bone scan.  That will help with the planning process.    As far as work goes, I work for a medical device company and can relate to the many physician/residency programs that we constantly have.  No one misses work at my company, ever.  But, it took one of my closest friends to say that her sister took off one entire year to heal at her job as an episcopalian minister.  I figured if she could do that, then so could I.  I decided on doing chemo on Mondays, so that I could recover (to some extent) during the week to be better for the kids hockey/basketball/scouts etc on the weekends.  We will see about work.   There are some things you can do about the sickness issue - ensure that you have big tables to stand behind when interviewing like at BID.  You can have both kleenex and and hand sanitizer, then you can blame it all on the H1N1 scare.  Everyone would expect that a Harvard facility would have extremely high standards for health and wellness.   Hang in there...i only had a few really bad days, they were ALL related to the post BMX body scans.  KEEP YOUR BRAIN/BODY BUSY...do not think about the scans, if you can.  As my onco nurse said when she gave me the result "well, you should not be nervous, you knew it would be negative...that is what we expected."  I quickly responded, that I was not feeling lucky. Prayers for calm as we all begin our January chemo...was just thinking that there is simply no better time to do chemo than January into spring...let's get this thing done!!!!!! Annie

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2011 05:29AM Anniemomofthree wrote: Hi MaryMeg - just read more about NZ earthquake.  So sorry for the pain pain suffering there. Its does seem so unfair to get hit so recently.  I hope things get stabilized soon.   I am on TCH - Taxotere, Carboplatin, and Herceptin.  I just finished round 3 of 6.  Halfway done!!! My first round was not good.  I had NO pre-meds.  I had aloxi/ativan/benadryl, and the chemo drugs in my chemo drip.  Went home with zofran, compazine and ativan.  Took my meds sequentially, but I did not overlap them, at all. Got behind on my fluids, because I was so nauseated.  Went in on day 8, for more fluids and more anti-nausea drugs.  Here is what I learned.  The drugs act have different actions, so they should be overlapping, take them all if you need to!  Diarhhea needs to be stopped, even though you may have constipation too (that was confusing to me as the constipation was a problem on day 3.  Hives are unique and you should use more benadryl.  Lost 7 pounds in 8 days.  Could hardly walk.  Slept/fidgeted alot.  Finally felt semi-normal on day 12. Here is what they changed for rounds 2-6:  Took chemo down 15% (just got it back up another 5% per my urging).  Premeds: decadron (steroid) and EMEND (love it).  Day of chemo - aloix/ativan/benadryl (half doase so I was not so out of it) and the chemo drugs.  Each day for two days - Emend at home in pill form.  Decadron (4mg) one in am, one in pm for four days. For round 2, I felt absolutely 100% the entire post chemo. worked out, walked the dog, made school lunches at 6:30am, lasted all the way to 11pm for bed. No naps. Ran errands, bugged my family because I did not have enough to do.  This regime really worked...will see about round #3. I am hopeful.  Alos, had I not gone in for round #2, I am sure that I would be feeling awful... I hope this helps.  i do not want anyone to go through chemo like I did for round #1.   Hugs to you and the rest of the chemo sisters out there! Annie

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2011 12:04PM Anniemomofthree wrote: Yes, I have been on the breast site.   It is a great site, but since there are alot of "problems" it did freak me out a bit.   I am really bony on top too.  That is why the cocos look so strange.  That and my port sticks out like one of those ritz bits with peanut butter!  My main worry was the falling foob which I saw online. that is why I have been concerned about going to big and destroying my thin muscle wall.  My PS did a great job of explaining the natural breast fold and where he works in that fold.  He also explained why other PS work above the fold and have the fall. He did assure me that, even though I am really thin (I know, the weight does not show that, but for 5'10" I am thin!) I had an excellent muscle wall to work within.  That is the kind of discussion we had.   Right now, he is satisfied with where they are, how they are sitting, the incisions look great (one of my worries) and that is why he will do 5 weeks post chemo.  The most helpful site for me has been the one that women want to stay small...A/B.  My PS and I keep discussing how I can go as big as I want, due to to height.  But, really, I want to be on the smaller side of things.  I am definitely not a boob gal, especially after they tried to kill me once!!!   What did whippetmom suggest?  I have not asked her specifically yet....

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2011 02:55PM Anniemomofthree wrote: SueBee - I wanted to comment on the beef issue.  My onco had casually mentioned that I may need a transfusion after round #2.  I was really surprised.  My hemoglobin went from 11.3 (7 weeks ago)  to 10.3 to 9.3 then to 9.0. They transfuse at about 8.5.  So i researched good sources of iron to build it back up. The best I found was on the CDC website.  It lists the iron sources and the milligrams for each product.  I was amazed to see the iron rates in fortified cereal - 18mg in some (which is the daily recommended for a 2000 calorie diet).  With certain types of iron (non-heme, which means not from meat) you need vitamin C (like OJ) to help the non-heme iron absorb.  Anyway, in 5 days, after eating alot of fortified cereals, a lot of beef (not my norm) and taking 18mg iron in my multivitamin I raised it back to 9.7!  You can do it too.  Sorry for this long post....

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2011 09:55PM Anniemomofthree wrote: Hi Everyone...it has taken me a while to get back on the board.  I have been trying to get used to my new diagnosis.  It was therapeutic to read the notes that people have written over the last two weeks.  I am now three weeks out TODAY.  I was really lucky that I did not experience any pain related to the bilateral mastectomy, thanks to my good friend and anesthesiologist.  I was able to use the ON Q Pain pump, so I had days of no pain within the hospital (except for 20 minutes, when I was holding the actual pain pump balls and my muscle spasmed) , then no pain after.  Yes, I do still take some tylenol for tightness.  This can be a really great and well managed surgery!  Breasts look good too...it is all relative! IT has taken me a while, because, I like many of you, had a change in the path report.  I went from a stage 0 to a 1A and will now do chemo.  I am not the depressed kind of person, but I spent 5 weeks waiting for surgery thinking that I had hit the jackpot to have just DCIS.  Then, post surgery, I got the clean report that it all looked good - SNB was negative, blah blah blah.  Then, on day three in the hospital, my surgeon suddenly appeared at 6pm.  Should have known something was up.  She shared that there were two tumors within the area of DCIS - one was 4mm, the other was 9mm.  15 mammograms, countless biopsies, MRI, clip in the are of the DCIS and they still did not see the other tumors.  What a bummer.  But, now I completely understand what the term "dense breasts" means...they can not see a darn thing.  Literally.  I liken it to watching a snowstorm through a window at the airport and you can see the 747s coming in for a landing, but you can not see the 3 small planes that crashed.  Somehow, this needs to be changed.  I did talk this through with my Drs. and all agreed that this is exactly the case, the radiologists CAN NOT SEE.  So, they give you a negative mammogram with a single line disclaimer  "despite extremely dense breasts."   So, I have been trying to come to terms with the new news.  It has taken a while to wrap my head around this...I sort of have felt like an idiot in that I did not understand this small detail. But, I think I am finally getting my positive mojo back.  Finally!   I am thankful that we have this wonderfully simple and straightforward option called surgery for BC.  Chemo is another incredibly wonderful option, too.   And, hair is kind of overrated.  I am lying on this one...as my 7 year old cried - "no bald mommy".  My others - 11 an 12 - have reminded my over and over that hair grows back.   Visi, Westielve, Megan, and all the rest of the sisters, here's to a wonderful and healing filled 2011.  We are going to collectively kick BC in the butt! Annie

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2011 09:33AM Anniemomofthree wrote: HI January BMX Ladies - I wanted to comment quickly - I had my BMX on Dec 11 (3.5 weeks ago) and it was SOOOO  easy.  I think i pored through each and every posting looking for someone that said it was easy.  In contrast, I just got my port today and I actually have some pain.  So, here is the scoop, my anesthesiologist used the ON Q PAIN PUMP, which is an intravertrebal pain pump.  I had it in for the duration of my three night stay at the hospital.  My BS, PS, and Anesthesiologist argued the entire time I was at the hospital about when to take this out.  I ended up keeping it for 3-4 days.  I went home on normal post BMX meds, when they ran out, I went on tylenol for a few days and that was it.  I realized today that I have not taken anything for pain in four days - until this port was placed today.     My anesthesiologist and I talked today about my lack of pain/lack of discomfort with the BMX.  He said that this is what he sees when they use the ON Q.  The concept is that you stop the nerves from firing (which is what they are supposed to do) and by a few days out, the nerves stop completely.  He is currently trying to do this on a patient with chronic post BMX pain - training the nerves to stop firing.     I was up and moving, sleeping in my own bed, entertaining, etc. the first week home.  i got my drains out on day #5.  I was in jeans and t-shirts shopping on day #6.  I had five house guests for 8 days.  Really, this is a very doable surgery.  I would highly recommend you advocate for yourself and say "my goal is to have a 0 or 1" pain experience.  There is no reason to have great pain, if you get behind in the pain management, you can let it linger for weeks, months... I did spend a month strengthening my core with yoga - especially focusing on the should flex since you have to lie flat while in surgery.  Seemed to help. I did feel strong!!!  My wish for the January crew is to talk to your team.  Get a plan that is consistent with your wishes.  Ask for what YOU want.  It is your body, and frankly your dime, too! All my love to you all!  Stay strong....talk to you all on the other side of this all.    Annie
